text:
NICK ROMEO: If you listen to
how a lot of mainstream media

and also mainstream economists
discuss unemployment,

you hear there's an ideal
level of unemployment.

And so the coverage
and the discussion

all focuses on whether what the
fed is doing with interest rates

is going to get us
to that ideal level

and how that might
impact inflation.

But it's actually
a little perverse

to say that there is some
ideal rate of joblessness.

No one would really argue
for an ideal rate of hunger

or an ideal rate of lack
of access to education.

A necessary first
step is to kind

of transcend the
simple assumption

that we have to have a
certain level of unemployment.

We can kind of turn the knobs on
the machine that is the economy
until we optimize it.

But look, the knobs themselves
are constraining our thinking.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Economics in universities
today is often

taught in a way that
suggests it's really just
one of the natural sciences.

This is a deeply misguided
and misleading way
of teaching the subject.

In fact, it's much closer to a
branch of political philosophy.

One of the best ways
to think about what's

wrong with academic economics is
to think about a quote from John
Maynard Keynes.

He once said that
the master economist

has four elements-- historian,
statesman, philosopher,
and mathematician.

That final element is something
that academic economics
tends to do very well.

Mathematics, history,
philosophy, politics--

the exclusion of
those elements really

from the curriculum,
that's, I think,

in a nutshell what's wrong with
a lot of academic economics.

Business leaders can
really take advantage

of a highly mathematized
view of the economy

to say there are just
these lawlike forces.

Increasing wealth concentration,
increasing concentration

of corporate power, the
impact of externalities

onto the natural world-- all of
these things are just inevitable
features.

If you don't want
nice things, then you

have to go back
to the stone age.
There's just no other option.

The move from math
to inevitability
is really the crucial one.

It's a very dangerous way of
shutting down conversation

by a false analogy
to natural laws.

If, on the contrary,
you see the economy

as a deeply human sphere
that inevitably reflects

moral choices, political
assumptions, then much more
is sort of up for grabs.

Suddenly, debate,
discussion, and progress
seem much more possible.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

It's understandable that
CEOs, especially who

are answerable to shareholders,
might feel constrained

to implement more humane
living wages, for instance,
or workplace conditions.

But there are already
businesses that

are paying something
close to a genuine living

wage, a very capacious
wage that recognizes
the value of employees.

Their success also reflects a
growing desire among consumers.

On some level,
most people do care

about the products
and services they

receive not being deeply
implicated in profound suffering
and misery.

So imagine that you could have
a very cheap chocolate bar only

on the condition that young
children in your neighborhood

will both be deprived
of an education

and will work really brutal
hours in difficult conditions

to grow the cocoa that's going
to end up in your chocolate bar.

Most people, if
they were presented

with a choice in such stark
terms, would say absolutely,
I do not want the chocolate bar.

It might seem a little
surprising to say,

in fact, that is the
current condition for much,
not only chocolate--

take coffee, take tea, take
meats, take electronics.

A huge range of
consumer products

only reach us at
the very low prices

that we pay for them
because of the suffering

of vulnerable people
and also the degradation
of our natural world.

So it's standard to
assume within a kind

of traditional economic
framework externalities

to economic transactions are
one, kind of hard to measure,

and two, should not
really be put back
into the price mechanisms.
You kind of just ignore them.
That's how stuff gets to us.

In fact, there is
another option.

There are people
in the Netherlands,

especially in Amsterdam,
using a family

of accounting methods sometimes
called true cost accounting
or true price accounting.

The basic intuition here
is that we're not paying
the full price for products.
Think about a hamburger.
Think about an apple.

Think about really
anything that you consume.

There are all of
these hidden costs.

We don't have a single
comprehensive signal
of all of those externalities.

So true price says,
what if we did?

What if we actually knew all
of the relevant externalities
for a product.

We took that price, and
then we put that back

into the pricing
of itself, which

would make dramatically higher
prices for many products, which
would partly be the point.

You would want to
shift consumer behavior

by giving people accurate
information about what
the costs are.

With the extra money,
you now have an option

to try to remediate
some of those harms.

I absolutely think there's a lot
of hope for the transformation
of how Econ 101 functions.

The Core economy textbook
is this very interesting
interdisciplinary project.

The authors have expertise
in all sorts of fields

to create a textbook
that's really much more
capacious in its vision.

It includes more of the
political, moral, historical

elements of
economics, and it also

has a lot of sophisticated
math and modeling.
So it's a false choice.

We can't sacrifice the kind
of clarity of our modeling,

so we'll just jettison all of
the humanistic elements that

are really inseparable
from economics.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
